This category is created to address subject-specific queries related to Tools in Data Science

- Why should people use this category? What is it for?


The larger goal of the Discourse forum is to act as a Knowledge base for the course. You can make this more productive by

Elaborating your question sufficiently and supporting it with steps that you have already tried at your end before posting this question

Sharing additional content or explanations related to the topic being discussed

-  Are there any rules for posting in this category?


Before you create a new post, review the existing threads to see if there are already highly similar or identical postings. Discourse will suggest similar posts once you start typing titles

Tag the post appropriately so that it gets indexed correctly in our Knowledge Base. For instance, if your query is on an Activity Question in Week 1 then use the tags #activity-question, #week-1

Provide a meaningful title to your post that contains the topic/details of your query so that it can be searched by others easily. For instance: Do not use the titles like “AQ1.1 Q3” which just gives question number alone. Instead use a more meaningful title like - “Need help in calculating the 
𝑁
𝑡
ℎ
N
th
 prime number”

Type in your question and explanations rather than pasting images or screenshots.

- What is NOT Permitted in this category?


Being argumentative or sarcastic

Use of abusive/strong language

Posting support/logistics related query

Unnecessarily tagging Faculty/Instructors in posts

Posting Solutions or discussing solutions to graded assignments

- Who will be moderating the content in this forum?


The foum will be moderated by Course Instructors. They will have the authority to decide whether a post violates forum rules/guidelines. You can flag/report any such violations that you observe by clicking on  icon on the post. Please do mention the reason why you are flagging the topic.

  - What are the disciplinary actions if some one violates the rules and guidelines of the forum? 


The flagged posts that violates forum rules/guidelines will be hidden. Repeated violation of the rules can result in the offender being removal from the forum.

I Kindly need Help with LLM CLI Tool – Model Authentication Issue with Models other OpenAI models.

I’ve been trying to go a bit deeper into Module 1 after completing GA1, and I’ve encountered some issues while experimenting with the llm CLI tool and different models.

Specifically, I tried running the following command to test the Gemini model, as shown on the Module 3 introduction page:

llm 'What is 2 + 2?' -m openrouter/google/gemini-2.0-flash-lite-001


But I received the following error:

Error: Error code: 401 - {'error': {'message': 'No auth credentials found', 'code': 401}}


Initially, I had set my OpenAI key from AIPipe , but I got a “model not found” error. So I checked the available models using:

llm model list


At that point, the Gemini model wasn’t listed.

I then installed the llm-openrouter plugin, and after that, the Gemini model appeared in the list. However, I’m now facing the above authentication error.

To test if the issue was only with Gemini and other models other than OpenAI models , I created a personal API key from OpenRouter and tried running a free model:(i tried free models on both keys from AIpipe and my personal account since it doesn’t need any credits to be purchased)

llm 'What is 2 + 2?' -m openrouter/qwen/qwen3-8b:free


This worked correctly with my OpenRouter API key, which confirms that the plugin is working fine.

I’m confused about how to properly authenticate for other via AIPipe for OpenRouter using the llm CLI. I’ve been trying different approaches for the last two days but haven’t been able to resolve this.
Certainly! Here’s a grammatically correct and polished version of the message you want to add at the end:

I also tried setting the API keys individually for OpenAI, OpenRouter(this is basically configured while installing the plugin llm-openrouter), and even my personal keys, using the key management options mentioned in the llm documentation. Additionally, I saw that our course page suggest changing the base URL like this:

export OPENAI_BASE_URL=https://aipipe.org/openrouter/v1
llm 'What is 2 + 2?' -m openrouter/google/gemini-2.0-flash-lite-001


However, even this approach didn’t work for me.

Could you kindly guide me on how to resolve this issue?

Thank you for your time and help.

Sincerely,
Meikanda Sivam

The Python code given in the “Images: Compression” section needs rectification. On reviewing the code below, I saw the following issues:

Not using await inside an async function.
compress_image(…) is marked ‘async’, even though it doesn’t really do anything asynchronous. If I am not mistaken, PIL operations (like img.convert(…)) are synchronous and blocking.
from pathlib import Path
from PIL import Image
import io

async def compress_image(input_path: Path, output_path: Path, quality: int = 85) -> None:
    """Compress an image while maintaining reasonable quality."""
    with Image.open(input_path) as img:
        # Convert RGBA to RGB if needed
        if img.mode == 'RGBA':
            img = img.convert('RGB')
        # Optimize for web
        img.save(output_path, 'WEBP', quality=quality, optimize=True)

# Batch process images
paths = Path('images').glob('*.jpg')
for p in paths:
    await compress_image(p, p.with_suffix('.webp'))



Removing async and await worked fine for me.

Note to Moderators: Kindly keep this active or (in case there is already a similar post) merge it with a related post.

 Time, Method, URL

URL → needed

 PUT – Correct: It replaces the resource entirely. Multiple identical PUTs = same result.

 GET – Also correct: It only fetches data, no side-effects. Multiple GETs = same result.

 DELETE – Technically correct: Deleting the same resource multiple times has the same result as deleting once (resource stays deleted).

Mock Exam: Tools in Data Science
The end term and the mock has been created using the TDS GPT Assistant. Since the GPT has ALL the GAs, Course Content Modules, Live Session Transcriptions (its works like RAG), it is really able to help you prepare for the end term. Use it!

Therefore you can also create your own mocks.

ChatGPT
ChatGPT - IITM TDS Teaching Assistant

TA for IIT Madras' Data Science course, guiding students with questions.

Below are variant questions across various topics relevant to the course. These questions have been curated from the topics areas we are focussing on. Therefore it will be very similar in content to the end term.

What it does not contain: Scenario based questions. These are complex to construct. We will address the topics for these questions in the live session.

LLMs
Pandas
Git, Docker, Bash
Q1: HTTP Method Semantics

Which HTTP method is not idempotent, meaning repeated identical requests may result in different outcomes each time?

A. GET
B. PUT
C. POST
D. DELETE

Answer: C. POST

Q2: IDE Features

Which feature is least likely to be found in a standard code editor or IDE?

A. Code formatting tools
B. Integrated terminal
C. Git integration
D. Cloud hosting of Docker containers

Answer: D. Cloud hosting of Docker containers

Q3: Pandas Summary Methods

You have a DataFrame with a region column. To get a quick summary of how many entries are in each region, which method is most useful?

A. df.describe()
B. df[“region”].value_counts()
C. df.count()
D. df.groupby(“region”).sum()

Answer: B. df[“region”].value_counts()

Q4: Python Exception Scope

You want to safely open a file, handle any errors, and ensure the file is always closed in Python. Which pattern should you use?

A. try: open(...) then finally: close()
B. open() and then except
C. open() and then raise
D. Use with open(...) as f: block

Answer: D. Use with open(...) as f: block

Q5: Chrome DevTools - Debugging

A frontend developer wants to trace JavaScript function calls step-by-step. Which Chrome DevTools panel should they use?

A. Console
B. Application
C. Sources
D. Elements

Answer: C. Sources

Q6: Data Cleaning Tools

You are cleaning survey responses and want to automatically match similar text entries like “NYC”, “New York City”, and “newyorkcity”. Which approach/tool would be most effective?

A. TRIM() in Excel
B. Manual Find and Replace
C. Fuzzy matching or clustering in OpenRefine
D. COUNTIF()

Answer: C. Fuzzy matching or clustering in OpenRefine

Q7: Geospatial Libraries

Which pair of Python libraries is best suited for geospatial analysis and rendering static maps?

A. pandas and seaborn
B. geopandas and matplotlib
C. folium and flask
D. sklearn and dash

Answer: B. geopandas and matplotlib

Q8: Statistical Significance

A psychologist tests if a training program changes memory performance and finds a p-value of 0.08. What can be concluded at the 0.05 significance level?

A. The result is highly significant
B. The null hypothesis must be rejected
C. There is insufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis
D. The program is proven to work

Answer: C. There is insufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis

Q9: Purpose of Kumu

What is a key use case for a tool like Kumu?

A. Animating time series
B. Designing deep learning models
C. Visualizing stakeholder networks and system relationships
D. Performing statistical analysis

Answer: C. Visualizing stakeholder networks and system relationships

Q10: DevTools Performance Diagnostics

To diagnose a slow webpage, you want to analyze scripts, rendering times, and long tasks. Which DevTools panel provides a timeline-based view?

A. Elements
B. Performance
C. Network
D. Lighthouse

Answer: B. Performance

Q11: Git Configuration

Which of the following files helps configure a Git project’s name, email, and default branch?

A. .gitignore
B. .gitattributes
C. .git/config
D. README.md

Answer: C. .git/config

Q13: Safe HTTP Method

Which HTTP method is considered safe, meaning it is only used for retrieval and must not change server state?

A. GET
B. DELETE
C. PATCH
D. POST

Answer: A. GET

Q14: Deduplicating Text Entries

A dataset has entries like “IBM”, “I.B.M.”, and “International Business Machines”. What is the best tool to cluster these for cleaning?

A. Excel TRIM
B. OpenRefine using key collision or fingerprinting
C. pandas merge()
D. CONCATENATE()

Answer: B. OpenRefine using key collision or fingerprinting

Q15: Geospatial + Interactive Mapping

A conservation biologist wants to visualize real-time animal tracking data on an interactive map. Which libraries would be best?

A. geopandas and plotly
B. folium and pandas
C. seaborn and shapely
D. rasterio and altair

Answer: B. folium and pandas

Q16: Pandas - Filtering Unique Entries

You have a DataFrame of customer orders and want to list only those customers who ordered once. Which Pandas method chain is most suitable?

A. df.groupby(“customer”).sum()
B. df[“customer”].value_counts() == 1
C. df.drop_duplicates()
D. df[“customer”].nunique()

Answer: B. df[“customer”].value_counts() == 1

Q17: Purpose of Kumu in System Design

How does Kumu help in system design or stakeholder mapping?

A. Organizing spreadsheets
B. Identifying leverage points in complex systems through visual maps
C. Rendering line graphs
D. Sending notifications

Answer: B. Identifying leverage points in complex systems through visual maps

Q18: Python Exception - Multiple Handlers

Which structure allows Python to handle different types of exceptions separately?

A. try…finally
B. if…else
C. Multiple except blocks
D. Nested try blocks

Answer: C. Multiple except blocks

Q19: Understanding Statistical Power

If a study has low statistical power, what is most likely to occur?

A. False positive (Type I error)
B. False negative (Type II error)
C. Confounding
D. Multicollinearity

Answer: B. False negative (Type II error)

Q20: Git Basics - Staging Area

Which Git command moves modified files to the staging area?

A. git push
B. git add
C. git fetch
D. git init

Answer: B. git add

Q21: Chrome DevTools - Local Storage

Where can you inspect local storage items (e.g. tokens, preferences) in Chrome DevTools?

A. Console
B. Application > Local Storage
C. Elements
D. Sources

Answer: B. Application > Local Storage

Q22: Chrome DevTools - JS Performance

Which DevTools feature helps measure execution time of scripts and CPU usage?

A. Console
B. Network
C. Performance
D. Application

Answer: C. Performance

Q23: Excel Data Import - Scientific Notation Issue

You import a CSV file where product IDs like "1E10" are being interpreted as scientific notation in Excel. What is the best way to preserve these IDs as text?

A. Format the column as General
B. Use =TEXT(A1, "0") after import
C. Set column format to Text during import or Text-to-Columns
D. Change regional settings

Answer: C. Set column format to Text during import or Text-to-Columns

Module: Everyday Tools

Q1: Spreadsheet Functions

You have a dataset in Excel where column A contains full names in the format “Last Name, First Name”. Which function can you use to extract the first name into a separate column?

A. =LEFT(A1, FIND(",", A1)-1)
B. =RIGHT(A1, LEN(A1) - FIND(",", A1))
C. =MID(A1, FIND(",", A1)+2, LEN(A1))
D. =SPLIT(A1, ",")

Answer: C — The MID function extracts text from the middle of a string. By finding the position of the comma and adding 2 (to skip the comma and space), it extracts the first name. Option A extracts the last name, Option B results in an error due to incorrect syntax, and Option D is not a valid Excel function.

Module: Data Sourcing

Q2: Web Scraping Ethics

When performing web scraping to collect data, which of the following practices is considered unethical?

A. Respecting the website’s robots.txt file.
B. Sending requests at a rate that mimics human browsing behavior.
C. Scraping data from a website that requires login without permission.
D. Citing the source of the data collected.

Answer: C — Scraping data from a website that requires login without permission violates the site’s terms of service and user privacy. Options A, B, and D are ethical practices that respect the website’s policies and data ownership.

Module: Data Preparation

Q3: Handling Missing Data

In a dataset, you notice that several entries in the “Age” column are missing. Which method is generally not appropriate for handling these missing values?

A. Replacing missing values with the mean age.
B. Deleting rows with missing age values.
C. Replacing missing values with a fixed age, such as 0.
D. Leaving the missing values as they are without any action.

Answer: D — Leaving missing values unaddressed can lead to errors in analysis and modeling. Options A, B, and C are common strategies for handling missing data, depending on the context and the extent of the missingness.

Module: Data Analysis

Q4: Statistical Measures

Which of the following statistical measures is not sensitive to extreme values (outliers) in a dataset?

A. Mean
B. Median
C. Standard Deviation
D. Range

Answer: B — The median represents the middle value of a dataset and is not affected by outliers. In contrast, the mean, standard deviation, and range can be significantly influenced by extreme values.

Module: Large Language Models

Q5: Tokenization in NLP

In Natural Language Processing, what is the primary purpose of tokenization?

A. To translate text from one language to another.
B. To split text into individual words or subwords.
C. To encrypt text for secure communication.
D. To summarize large texts into shorter versions.

Answer: B — Tokenization involves breaking down text into smaller components, such as words or subwords, which can then be processed by language models. This is a fundamental step in NLP tasks.

Module: Geospatial and Network Analysis

Q6: Geographic Coordinate Systems

Which of the following coordinate systems is commonly used to represent locations on Earth’s surface?

A. Cartesian Coordinate System
B. Polar Coordinate System
C. Geographic Coordinate System (Latitude and Longitude)
D. Cylindrical Coordinate System

Answer: C — The Geographic Coordinate System uses latitude and longitude to specify locations on Earth’s surface. This system is widely used in geospatial analysis.

Module: Data Visualization

Q7: Effective Data Visualization

When creating a bar chart to compare the sales performance of different products, which practice should be avoided?

A. Ordering bars from highest to lowest value.
B. Using different colors for each bar without a legend.
C. Starting the y-axis at zero.
D. Labeling each bar with its exact value.

Answer: B — Using different colors for each bar without a legend can confuse the audience, as they may assume the colors represent different categories. Consistency and clarity are key in effective data visualization.

Module: Everyday Tools

Q8: VS Code Feature Use

You are editing a Python script in Visual Studio Code and want to quickly find and edit all occurrences of a variable name in the current file. What feature should you use?

A. Git integration
B. Debug panel
C. Multi-cursor editing
D. Terminal commands

Answer: C — Multi-cursor editing allows you to place multiple cursors in a file and edit text in multiple locations at once. It is useful for refactoring variable names or repeated patterns.

Module: Data Sourcing

Q9: Data API Identification

Which of the following data sources is most likely to provide structured data accessible via an API?

A. A scanned PDF document
B. A screenshot of a chart
C. The World Bank data portal
D. A newspaper article

Answer: C — The World Bank data portal provides structured datasets accessible via APIs. The other options involve unstructured or image-based content not suitable for direct data access.

Module: Data Preparation

Q10: Data Type Conversion in Excel

You imported a CSV file into Excel, and one of the columns containing numbers is treated as text. What is the easiest way to convert it into numeric format?

A. Use the CONCAT function
B. Format the column as Text
C. Use the VALUE() function
D. Use SUBSTITUTE()

Answer: C — The VALUE function converts text that appears as numbers into actual numeric values. This is useful when data is imported with formatting issues.

Module: Data Analysis

Q11: Outlier Detection

You are analyzing a dataset of employee salaries. Which visualization is best for quickly identifying outliers?

A. Line chart
B. Box plot
C. Histogram
D. Pie chart

Answer: B — A box plot clearly shows the spread of data and highlights outliers as individual points beyond the whiskers.

Module: Large Language Models

Q12: Prompt Engineering Strategy

To get consistent, structured responses from a language model when extracting key information, which approach is most effective?

A. Ask the model to “summarize” the text
B. Use open-ended questions
C. Use system messages and JSON schema formatting
D. Provide only one-word inputs

Answer: C — System messages and structured output formats like JSON schemas guide the model to generate reliable and consistent structured responses.

Module: Geospatial and Network Analysis

Q13: Network Centrality

In a social network graph of coworkers, which metric best identifies the person who connects the most groups together?

A. Degree centrality
B. Closeness centrality
C. Betweenness centrality
D. Eigenvector centrality

Answer: C — Betweenness centrality measures how often a node appears on shortest paths between other nodes, highlighting connectors or “bridges” in the network.

Module: Data Visualization

Q14: Choosing the Right Chart

You want to show how the composition of a marketing budget changes across three years. Which visualization is most appropriate?

A. Pie charts for each year
B. Scatter plots
C. Stacked bar chart
D. Line chart

Answer: C — A stacked bar chart shows parts of a whole across different categories and time periods, making it easier to compare budget composition over years.

# TDS-Project2-QuestionBank
Question Bank for all TDS assignments

# Requested format
## Student Assignments Directory Structure

Each student has a folder named with their roll number. Inside each student's folder, there are multiple assignment folders (`Assignment_X`). Each assignment contains:
- A `.txt` file with the question statement.
- A corresponding `.py`, `.sh`, or `.js` file for the solution.

### Example Directory Structure
RollNo_12345/
├── Assignment_1/
│   ├── Q1.txt    # Question for Q1
│   ├── Q1.py     # Solution in Python
│   ├── Q2.txt    # Question for Q2
│   ├── Q2.sh     # Solution in Bash
│   ├── Q3.txt    # Question for Q3
│   ├── Q3.js     # Solution in JavaScript
├── Assignment_2/

Dear @jkmadathil @Anand @Bharathi

First and foremost, we sincerely appreciate the efforts of the TDS team in supporting us throughout this course. The live sessions and guidance have been helpful, and we recognize the intent to make this a valuable learning experience.

However, despite these efforts, many of us have faced significant challenges in keeping up with the course expectations.

Key Challenges Faced
 Lack of Prerequisites

This course did not list any prerequisites, leading many students—including those from non-technical backgrounds—to enroll with the expectation that they could keep up. However, the reality is that the course content, assignments, and projects have been far more complex than anticipated, making it difficult to manage.

 Project Complexity & Deadline Pressure

The difficulty of the projects has been overwhelming, requiring most of us to rely heavily on peer support just to meet the deadlines. Despite putting in our best efforts, many of us struggled to complete them successfully.

 Course Structure Changes & Misleading Past Feedback

Many students joined TDS based on past Discourse posts and feedback, which suggested a different course structure. With the recent changes, it has been a tough transition—especially for working professionals and students without prior experience.

 Remote Open Exam (RoE) & Graded Assignments (GAs)

While we have put in significant effort—spending 2-3 days on Graded Assignments (GAs) to secure good scores—we still find ourselves struggling to meet expectations for the projects and RoE, which are significantly harder than anticipated.

We completely understand the need to maintain academic standards, but we also hope fairness is considered. Since many of us are putting in our best efforts but still finding it hard to meet the course demands, we kindly request a revision of the grading pattern. Increasing the weightage of Graded Assignments (GAs) would help ensure that the dedication and hard work of students are fairly reflected in their grades. This would allow students to pass with a reasonable grade while still maintaining the integrity of the course.

We truly respect the effort that has gone into designing this course, and we are all here because we genuinely want to learn and grow. We only ask that the grading structure consider the diverse backgrounds of students so that everyone has a fair chance to succeed.

Thank you for your time and understanding. We appreciate your consideration and hope to find a way forward that benefits both students and the course objectives.

import gzip
import pandas as pd
from datetime import datetime

log_path = 's-anand.net-May-2024.gz'
start_time = datetime.strptime('01:00:00', '%H:%M:%S').time()
end_time = datetime.strptime('15:00:00', '%H:%M:%S').time()
log_data = []

def parse_log(line):
    parts = line.split(' ')
    log_time = datetime.strptime(parts[3][1:], '%d/%b/%Y:%H:%M:%S')
    method, url, status = parts[5][1:], parts[6], int(parts[8])
    return log_time, method, url, status

with gzip.open(log_path, 'rt') as file:
    for entry in file:
        log_time, method, url, status = parse_log(entry)
        if method == 'GET' and url.startswith('/blog/') and 200 <= status < 300:
            if log_time.weekday() == 0 and start_time <= log_time.time() < end_time:
                log_data.append(entry)

print(f"Successful GET requests: {len(log_data)}")


ps: I shared code after the deadline hopefully no issues there!

Dear Tds team @carlton @jkmadathil @Bharathi @andrew ,

I hope this message finds you well. I would like to clarify my position and outline the key concerns regarding the evaluation of Project 2.

Firstly, let me emphasize that I have no issue with the discussion, learning objectives, or goals of the project. In fact, I thoroughly enjoy challenges and have appreciated this course more than any other in the diploma program. However, there is a clear distinction between engaging in academic exploration and the critical impact of grading, which directly influences our final results.

Now, addressing the core issue:

Attached below is a screenshot of the final evaluation results:


image
1918×983 109 KB

These evaluation fields, which were hidden during the final evaluation, significantly affected (and, in my case, diminished) my final score. For instance:

ReadMe Evaluation:
How did the LLM determine that my ReadMe file lacked the necessary headings or structure? This judgment appears inconsistent and lacks transparency.
Chart Relevance:
How did the LLM evaluate the relevance of the charts in my submission? The charts I provided were entirely aligned with the project goals.

image
1412×969 104 KB

For reference, my submission can be reviewed here: GitHub Repository.

To explore alternative evaluation methods, if peer review had been used, I believe it is reasonable to estimate that my final score would have ranged between 80-90%. This aligns with the initial evaluation script, which scored my submission at 89% (14/14).


This created a false sense of confidence for many students, myself included, that our scripts were adequately optimized and would receive a decent grade (as the evaluation script used llm to determine the final grade for test cases and it took a lot of time to take it from 4/14 to 14/14). This lack of transparency in the evaluation process led to confusion and ultimately to disappointment when the final grades were released.

Critical Concerns:

Transparency:
How do you justify the drastic reduction of a score from 89% (based on the initial evaluation) to a mere 41% in the final evaluation? This inconsistency undermines the credibility of the grading system.
Integrity:
The final evaluation process appears to have serious flaws. A peer review would likely have produced a score closer to 90%, which is far more representative of the effort and quality of the submission. The current system’s inability to provide consistent and reliable results is concerning.
Impact on Grades:
The abrupt decline in scores has directly impacted our final grade points, in some cases, reducing them from a ‘B’ to a ‘C.’ This disproportionately penalizes students and fails to reflect their genuine efforts.

Proposed Solutions:

Reevaluate all submissions using a new and fair evaluation script (though I understand this might not be feasible at this stage).
Implement a peer review system to provide more accurate and balanced grading.
Accept the initial test results (14/14 scores) as the final results. While this may be a basic measure, it is at least consistent and reflective of the criteria we optimized our scripts for.

What cannot be done, however, is ignoring the evident flaws in the evaluation system. Students invested weeks optimizing their scripts (from scores like 4/14 to 14/14) based on the visible tests, only to be blindsided by a system that ultimately did not function as intended.

While I am not opposed to new evaluation systems or changes, it is essential that such systems work transparently and consistently to ensure fairness for all students.

Thank you for your time and consideration. I look forward to your response.

Sincerely,
Aditya Gupta

TDS Project 2 is available at tools-in-data-science-public/project-2-automated-analysis.md at tds-2024-t3 · sanand0/tools-in-data-science-public · GitHub

It’s an interesting project.

You have to write an LLM-based program to analyze a dataset.
You have to convince an LLM that your code and output are good.

This is hard. It’s something you haven’t done before. (Nor most people in the world.)

So I strongly urge you to start early!

Please use this thread for any questions.

You’ll learn a lot of new things. Enjoy the journey!

UPDATE: 7 Dec 2024. The WIP evaluation script is at tools-in-data-science-public/project2 at tds-2024-t3-project2-wip · sanand0/tools-in-data-science-public · GitHub

UPDATE: 12 Dec 2024. Frequently Asked Questions

When is Project 2 due? Before Mon 16 Dec 2024,3:30 pm IST.
Where do I submit? https://forms.gle/r2sNJvGicxrhE9mYA
Can I use my own OpenAI API key? Yes
Where should I store the token? In the AI_PROXY environment variable. Don’t commit your token.
What if I ran out of the $2 credit on my token? We’ve increased it to $5 for everyone. You will not get more. Borrow from friends if required.
How do I check how much credit I have used so far? Every response has a monthlyCost field. Keep that below 5.0.
Won’t passing images to OpenAI cost too much? Use "detail": "low" to reduce it.
What should my folder structure be?
autolysis.py
goodreads/README.md
goodreads/*.png
happiness/README.md
happiness/*.png
media/README.md
media/*.png
How should I run my autolysis.py? uv run autolysis.py /path/to/input.csv
Where should I save the README.md and PNG files? In the current working directory.
How can I check my submission? Use the WIP Project 2 Evaluation Script.
Where are the results of this stored?
Linux/Mac: ~/.local/share/tds-sep-24-project-2/results.csv
Windows: %LOCALAPPDATA%\tds\tds-sep-24-project-2\results.csv
LLMs are error prone. Should my code retry on failure? Yes. E.g. use a library like tenacity.
Will you evaluate the code multiple times and take an average? No. Just once.
How long can my code run? Max 120 seconds.
What if I get CLONE FAILED ... returned non-zero exit status 128.? Your GitHub repo URL is wrong or your repo is private.
Which datasets will you evaluate? The project mentions “one of the datasets you submitted”. We’ll run uv run autolysis.py on either goodreads.csv, happiness.csv, or media.csv, randomly, and evaluate it. We will also evaluate it on 2 secret datasets.
I get a No module named .... Read the uv reading material
I get a HTTP 429 error. OpenAI is tired. Retry.
I get a different score each evaluation. LLMs give different results each time. Make your code and prompts more robust.

UPDATE: 14 Dec 2024. More FAQs

But my code works on my system… It needs to work via the evaluate script too. This project teaches you portable and deployable coding.
But it worked last time… APIs are unreliable. Learn how to handle that, e.g. via retries, caching, timeouts, etc.
But I got a different score last time… LLMs are not deterministic. Learn how to handle that, e.g. via robust prompts.
But my code times out… Shorten your prompts. Reduce the number of LLM requests. Pray for luck.
What’s the max total from the evaluation script? 14 when you run it. When I run it, it’ll add 2 extra datasets taking the total to 20. (Plus 8 bonus marks for originality and 4 for wow factor. Finally, normalization.)
What if the code evaluation gives me contradictory feedback? The final code evaluation script is a secret. It’ll be far more granular. Use the evaluation output as a guide but focus on writing good code.
How do I handle No module named ...? Read the Project 2 reading material on uv
Should I pip install my dependencies? No. Read the Project 2 reading material on uv
Where should I save my generated README.md and PNG files?. In the current directory, NOT the script directory, nor the data directory.
How do I handle Your authentication token is not from a valid issuer...? Use http://aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev/openai/v1 as your OPENAI_API_BASE when using the openai library with AIProxy
I have a Readme.md but the evaluation script script says I dont. File names will be evaluated case-sensitively. Create a README.md and *.png in exactly that case.

UPDATE: 15 Dec 2024. Second submission evaluation.

I’ve evaluated 343 Project 2 submissions starting around 4 pm IST today.

Of these, 151 got 3/3, and these are PROBABLY OK. Others may copy your code. You might improve & test it locally for uniqueness and push before the deadline.

The remaining 192 submissions are not OK.

The evaluation is based on this evaluation script: tools-in-data-science-public/project2 at tds-2024-t3 · sanand0/tools-in-data-science-public · GitHub

The results are at: TDS Sep 2024 - Project 2 Evaluation 2024-12-15 - Google Drive

results.csv has the status of the submission checks for each student. If your ID is not here, then you have not submitted with your IITM email. Please submit again.

logs/ has the logs, i.e. your code output (if there was any). I run the evaluator 2-3 times since I ran out of tokens. So some of you may see the output of two runs.

The top problems I see are:

Saving files in the script or data directory instead of the current working directory.
Not using script metadata for uv, or trying to install via pip
Script runs forever. NOT due to LLMs, but waiting for interactive visualizations, starting HTTP servers, etc.
AI Proxy token is not set up correctly.

These are classic deployment mistakes. Please fix them.

Some of your repos are private. I guess you know what you’re doing.

I won’t be able to run more evaluations before the deadline, nor revert on this thread, given travel. I suggest you run the evaluation script (preferably without Python in the path, with the data in a faraway directory) to check if your code works.

TDS 2024 Sep Project 2 Results

View Project 2 results.

This is the evaluation process.

Analyzing the results.csv will be interesting. Please do share your analysis and learnings.

FAQ
But I get different results locally. ANS: Your code ran differently in the test environment. LLMs and environments are not deterministic. Write code more robustly.
What’s fatal: could not read Username for 'https://github.com': terminal prompts disabled? ANS: Your repo is private.
What’s missing autolysis.py? ANS: Your script was not named autolysis.py and present in the root folder. Maybe it had a different name or was in a different folder.
Why’s my README.md or *.png missing? ANS: Your script didn’t generate them, or saved them in a wrong location.
Why do output: wage_theft.csv, output: house_rent.csv get 0 points? ANS: They are not part of the evaluation. They’re just an informational check.
What is code_hacking? ANS: The code has content that nudges the LLM towards higher code quality scores? This does not affect your score, but re-runs the evaluation.
What is output_hacking? ANS: The output has content that nudges the LLM towards higher output quality scores. That gives you a tiny bonus and re-runs the evaluation.
Why does it praise my score and still give me 0? ANS: The prompt instructs it to always tell you what’s good AND bad, irrespective of the score.
How was the code diversity bonus calculated? ANS: Using the % overlap (Jaccard similarity) with previous submissions. Bonus = Your marks * (1 - overlap) * 8 / 20
What about the “Engaging and interesting” bonus? ANS: None of the responses blew my mind. (Oh, there are very good ones, no doubt.) So I didn’t award any for this.

This concludes the Project 2 evaluation.

Fantastic work, everyone!!

TDS Project 1 has a peer evaluation component worth 20%.

Who evaluates? You will get an email today (2 Nov 2024) if:

Submitted a Git repo in Project 1, and
Didn’t get an error against “Your GitHub repo URL”
You are the first one to submit your repo. (If someone else submitted the same repo later, they don’t get the email. Yes, this happened with 1 repo )

By when to evaluate? By Fri 8 Nov EOD AoE, submit your form.

How to evaluate? The email will have 2 Git repo and 1 Google Form link. Go through both Git repos and answer all questions in the Google Form. (All questions are required.)

Log in with your IITM email ID and record that in the form.

The evaluation is on 2 subjective criteria, i.e. based on your opinion.

How INTERESTING are the findings in the repo’s README?
If there’s no README, assign 0
If you learnt something fascinating, assign 10
If it was in-between, assign the appropriate rating
How CLEAR and PROFESSIONAL is the repo’s code?
If there’s no code, assign 0
If the code was very clear and elegant, assign 10 (it’s OK that it’s subjective)
If it was in-between, assign the appropriate rating

How will scores be calculated? Your peer review score has a 20% weightage in Project 1.

You get +4% if you received an email and submitted the form with your IITM email ID before Fri 8 Nov EOD AoE.
You get between 0-16% based on the average of your peers’ evaluations.

When will the final scores be announced? By Wed 13 Nov EOD AoE. This will include your peer feedback ratings and text.

Dear all,

We are aware that there was a mistake in the deadline date of GA4. It was meant to be 25/10/2024 23:59 Hrs, however it was unintentionally closed at 5.29am.

Please rest assured, there are at least three alternative proposals being considered to mitigate this mistake on our part. Our goal is to make the restitution as painless as possible but also fair to those that submitted their assignments early. If you submitted early the full assignment we will still consider it for grading (aka you filled up all the answers).

[UPDATE: 31 Oct 2024]
The requirement for end term eligibility will be dropped from best 3 of first 5
to best 2 of first 5 graded assignments.

Likewise, the best 4 of 7 graded assignments will be considered for graded assignment score for the T value.

Please note Project is separate from Graded Assignments. Project is not part of the eligibility requirements nor is it part of the GA score calculation. Project has its own weight and contribution to the T score.

We will inform you of the resolution in a couple of days time. We are sorry for the inconvenience. Please prepare for your upcoming quiz and all the best for it.

Kind regards

Here’s the thing. Once you have the code in place and have received the API response in CSV format, you upload those CSVs to GitHub and start answering the questions. When you reach questions 11, 12, 13, and 15, you start wondering where things are going wrong. After reviewing all the hints, I realized that the code checking your answer treats “true” and “false” as strings. If you check the file uploaded on GitHub and look at the raw version, you’ll see that it has everything stored as either TRUE/FALSE or True/False. Opening the file on your machine doesn’t help, because Excel automatically interprets these values as booleans.

Here’s what I did—not the best method, and I’m sure someone could code a solution, but I did the best I could. I copied the raw file content from GitHub and pasted it into a Word document. I replaced all instances of FALSE with false and TRUE with true, then copied that back into the GitHub raw file and committed the changes.

Once done, return to the project page and enter the same answers you initially got through your code or manual calculations, and you’ll see things align. I know this isn’t the most elegant solution, and I should handle it programmatically, but sometimes you have to implement fixes that work rather than seeking the most elegant solution. Hope this helps!

Here is an OPTIONAL project: Record a 10-minute video in which you create an application entirely using LLMs and deploy it.

Any app is fine. Any language. Simple or complex. Business or gaming. Anything is fine. Your choice.
Create the app only using LLMs. You can use an LLM (ChatGPT, Claude.ai, Gemini, Cursor, Cody, etc.) but you can only prompt the app to write code. You can copy-paste code and run code don’t write or edit even a single line of code directly. Use LLMs to debug and edit. Code completion is NOT allowed – only prompting/chatting.
Record the entire process in 10 min. Don’t edit, trim, enhance, or annotate the video. You should record yourself creating the entire app from start to finish. Practice beforehand if you like. Record in 1 take.
Share the video and app. Publish the video publicly anywhere (e.g. YouTube and share the link.) Publish the app publicly anywhere (e.g. GitHub pages, Glitch.me, Heroku, etc.) or upload a ZIP file with the code (for slightly lower marks.)

Submit via a reply to this thread. Multiple submissions per person are fine. Work in groups if you like but only the submitter gets marks.

I will award up to 1 bonus mark at my discretion based on:

How well you prompt the LLM
How impressive the app is (if you’ve hosted it - I probably won’t run your code)
How closely you followed the rules above

This exercise is to help you (and me) learn a topic that’ll probably change the way we all code: using LLMs to code.

Cutoff date: 7 Oct 2024, AoE

Here is a summary of Week 1 TA session, in order to save you time from watching 2 hours of ASMR. For those that want fat free info:

TDS is practical.
READ the Course Introduction LOTs of invaluable Information.
Start preparing for ROE NOW.
End term is theory based and is much easier than GAs, Projects, ROE.
Project Score = 80% based on answers to project questions + 20% are from Peer Reviews.
Project comprises of Quantitative and Qualitative. Peer reviews are on the qualitative part. Reviews that are outliers are rejected.
Bonus Marks are only on Discourse. Answers must be submitted according to the Discourse post. Discretion of Bonus Marks are upto how impressed the Prof is with your submission.
Bonus Marks are really worth it. In total they are worth half of the total GAs.
Also Bonus Marks are great fun!
ROE Mocks are just previous ROEs.
There is no pattern for ROEs. They are never the same as previous ROEs.
However core skills of ROEs remain the same:

Scraping webpages. HTML, CSS, Javascript (particularly for selecting dom elements), sessions, cookies.
Scrapping PDFs. Python Tabula library.
Python (especially Pandas)
Nominatim
SQL
and maybe some other minor tools.

ROE week content: Week 2 to 4
ROE is open book (not proctored, use anything you wish including GPT)
ROE is very, very hard. Start preparing now.
SCT is NOT required for ROE.

Week 5: you will get some $ allowance for LLM tokens. Awesome. And super fun topic.

Optional Videos in week 2 are NOT optional. They are a necessary for ROE (and end term).

Bonus 1: Making LLM app: Just sharing the code on Github is not an app. Github and Github Pages are NOT the same thing. Github Pages is a web server where you can deploy your app. Github repo is just a place to store and share your code. An app is a working application that anyone with web access can use just by clicking on the link you provide.

Your app has to be submitted in the Discourse post where the Bonus post was made.

Subscribe to Discourse emails for TDS. That way you will not miss important information like the Bonus questions.

Listen to Podcast - very informational about current data science industry.

BASH - there is a great book for this from System Commands.

accounts.google.com
Google Drive: Sign-in

Access Google Drive with a Google account (for personal use) or Google Workspace account (for business use).

The links at the bottom and top of videos in the modules are very valuable.

Week 1 Video session is available on the TDS You Tube Video Playlist.


Access will NOT be given to the video links in the calendar. The ONLY place to get access to the videos will be the TDS You Tube Video Channel.

Kind regards,
TDS TA

In light of the issues raised by students in Discourse regarding Project 1, the following remedial measures are being taken:

Regarding Issue of “Submit Button” for the Quantitative Submission
We have been made aware that several students submitted test runs for their project submissions and then were notified that their project has not been received. We are able to see any test runs that were submitted. We want to reassure you, if you did your "Test Run", then your last "Test Run" submission will still be considered.
If you encountered the above problem or any other portal problems, please send some evidence of the problem you encountered in this discourse thread. This will help the operations team to diagnose why this error occurred. Screenshots, error messages, etc would be helpful. Please keep everything in a single post per student (i.e do not make multiple post submissions)

Please use the poll below to indicate your issue and provide a detailed response as a reply to this post.

 I was unable to click on “Submit” button, but I was able to click on “Test Run”
 I was neither able to click on “Submit” nor “Test Run”

13
voters
 Votes are public.
Results
Regarding submission issues related to Peer Reviews for Project 1
Clarification
Peer Review submission = You submit for review from others + You review submission given by others

And there is a causal link between these two, i.e., you submit for getting review from others and hence you receive and hence you get an opportunity to review others. It should not be treated as mutually independent events

The opportunity being provided now is for those who faced technical issues in either of the parts and due to which they were unable to submit.

On  Friday, August 9, 2024 12:00 PM, we will open the peer review submissions for Project 1 and this will be open till  Saturday, August 10, 2024 12:00 PM. The reviews will have to be subsequently completed by  Sunday, August 11, 2024 12:00 PM. This will be your last window to submit your part 2 submission and its peer reviews. If you encounter any problems on the day, please get straight away in touch with us through this discourse thread, so that the operations team can in real time evaluate the problem that you are encountering and get you a resolution.
If you are unable to access the review submissions due to insufficient access privileges, give a zero for that review and move on to the next review.
Likewise please ensure that your project folder has been given full access permissions to “Anyone with the link”. Otherwise you will get a 0 from other reviewers.
If you have concerns about getting bad reviews, please read the Course introduction page, a clear detailed explanation is given with regards to how we handle anomalous reviews. So do not worry about it. Please do not fill up discourse with complaints about peer reviews. We have a mechanism to deal with it fairly. If on the other hand you have received 100% when you should not have… be ready to be evaluated fairly too. It cuts both ways.
Also, please note that we will be considering the marks for only those who had submission issues for the part 2 assignments earlier. In case you have already received your reviews, we will not be considering your review score for this assignment. In case you missed out on reviewing others in the earlier submission, reviewing as part of current submission will not fetch you marks.

Edit: Updated the nature of submission to include both Part 2 submission and its peer review and detailed out the cases that will be considered for final mark calculation.

claude.ai supports a feature called “Artifacts” (examples). You can have it build and publish web apps.

Here is an OPTIONAL project.

Build an app that solves question 1 on Graded Assignment 5.

The app should take 2 inputs:

The full text of the question (e.g. “Get a list of all OpenAI models that were created before … What is the correct total of points?”)
The user’s AIPROXY_TOKEN (don’t hard-code yours)

It should then use aiproxy.sanand.workers.dev to fetch the model list and answer the questions, eventually returning a number between 0-7.

(Obviously, you’ll need to prompt Claude to build this app – you can’t edit the code yourself.)

Once you’ve built the app, reply to this post with the link to your published app before Fri 19 July 2024 AoE.

You get 1 mark if the app works correctly.

Here are the commonly asked questions:

How do I solve this question / learn this topic?

Re-watch videos carefully with a focus on your specific problem / topic.
Solve with friends. You’ll both learn faster.
Ask ChatGPT. LLMs help you think. It’s good to practice with AI anyway.
Ask your TAs. Try solving / learning it yourself, first.
Try again later. Give it a few days, sleep over it, and try again.

When are live / TA sessions?

Live sessions are on Wednesdays at 9 pm IST from 12 June. TA sessions are on Thursdays and Sundays at 8 pm IST from 13 June. See the course calendar. The link is on the course introduction

Should I leave questions blank if I don’t know the answer?

No. There is no negative marking. Guess smartly for more marks.

In GA1, 75 students left an answer blank! One student got 3 questions right and left 7 blank (out of 10). It’s very likely they’d get 2 more marks from guessing.

Here’s my suggestion – but it’s your call.

If you didn’t submit the last ROE, take it. Even if you didn’t appear for it, you’re allowed this time, and there’s nothing to lose.
If you got 0/8 or 1/8, retake it. Even random guesses could improve your score.
If you got 2/8 or 3/8, join the ROE, look at the questions and decide. If you feel lucky, go ahead.
If you got 4/8 or above, don’t bother. Your score will likely go down.

If you join the ROE, accept the code of conduct, and DO NOT CLICK ANY ANSWER, this ROE score won’t count. You’re welcome to browse the questions.

If you join the ROE, accept the code of conduct, and CLICK ON EVEN ONE ANSWER even accidentally, your score WILL count and WILL replace your previous ROE score.

A few tips:

The questions are similar to the earlier ROE but are on a different dataset. Those who answered the last ROE have a slight advantage, so I’ve made the questions slightly harder. (“Yeah, as if the last ROE wasn’t hard enough! ”)
There’s an annoying alert “You are not allowed to switch tabs/windows” that’ll appear. Sorry. Please copy the questions to Notepad or whatever and work there.
Getting into the right mood helps a lot. Do whatever gets you there.

Welcome to the second ROE!

What an ROE experience!

In short, the portal said you had an hour. But you actually had only 45 minutes. Your responses weren’t auto-submitted. Our mistake.

Please be gentle on the TAs. This is an operational miss. They spotted it early, but it wasn’t fixed on time.

You now have the OPTION of taking another ROE on Sun 28 July at 4:00 pm IST for 45 min.

This ROE will be just like the previous one. Same difficulty. Same syllabus. But different datasets and slightly different techniques.

If you take this 2nd ROE, ONLY the 2nd ROE score will be used (not the best of the two).

If you don’t take this 2nd ROE, your 1st ROE score will be used (or zero if you didn’t take/submit the first one.)

This ROE will be on the exam portal. Your answers will be auto-saved. (The exam portal is usually proctored, but this exam won’t be. Use the Internet, friends, whatever. If the portal warns not to open other tabs or windows, ignore them.)

There will be a G-Meet and a Discourse thread active during the ROE to resolve issues quicker. They’re optional. Join either if you have a query.

To avoid overloading you, we’ll space things out a bit.

GA6 & GA7 will be released Mon 29 Jul, after the 2nd ROE.
Project 1 submission is extended to Wed 24 Jul. Peer reviews are due by Fri 31 Jul.
Project 2 submission will be released on Mon 5 Aug. Submission is due on Mon 19 Aug. Peer reviews are due by Mon 26 Aug.

I initially wrote a much longer much rantier version of this, but having calmed down somewhat, my thoughts on the 3 submissions I’ve seen so far.

Q1

To begin with, the point headers for both documents - the cleanup document & the inferences document, are 100% identical for question 1 across all 3 of the submissions I’ve graded so far.

Regarding the inferences, I feel like there’s a quantity vs quality issue here. IF I were grading you on the actual strength of your inferences, I don’t want 11 points that just say “well here’s what we see in the chart”. I could just look at the chart to get that.
I want 1 - 3 points that you think through. You should start a point with “this phenomenon can be observed in the chart”, and then you should spend a paragraph or 2 exploring, hypothesizing why it happened, considering what it could possibly mean.

Regarding the data cleanup. You guys again just copy-pasted the exact same document which you got from God knows where, and for “bonus points” some of you included code snippets. And while you did cleanup every possible issue, that’s my problem.

No one said “I inspected the data, found so & so issues were present, and addressed those issues specifically before getting on with my work”. Whoever made this document thought to themselves “here’s every possible issue that this dataset could have actually contained as per the live sessions and discourse posts, look I handled all of them…even if some were not present in my state’s data”.

More problematically no one described at all anything they did to the state dataset after scraping & cleaning; no one wrote “now I made a pivot table with this as rows & this as columns & this as values to get the data in the format I needed to solve the question”.

Also why did none of the charts have chart titles? I haven’t reduced any gradings for this cuz the axes were labelled & titled, but come on this is just basics, include a title saying “plot of no. of times @21f3001724 has lost his temper and nearly given himself a heart attack”.
Otherwise, how would I as a client or independent reviewer even know what I was looking at if I had not also solved this project?

Q2
Question2 was sligthly less migraine inducing to read, mainly cuz I don’t think anyone made an inferences.docx template for it and so you guys needed to actually write something of your own (and look at the shock, even when I can tell the writer is not too confident with writing their own stuff, when they actually excercise their brains and try the results aren’t half bad).

Probably the funnniest part was when someone (you know who you are…unless multiple of you did this thing) copied the inferences point headers from Question 1 and then wrote things like (I’m paraphrasing)

“21st century shift - there is none because this is not time series data”
 Why would you mention that then?


image
750×1000 60 KB

You might think “hey my written reports are lackluster but that’s not my job I’m a data analyst I did the data analyzing part right?”
Well first off I don’t really care, and second off I’d say it does matter. Because my issue here is not “the report was badly written”. My issue here is that it was lazily written.

If was a professor, and a student came to me and gave me a report, and I saw it was full of spelling errors & grammatical errors, but that it was clearly something they had written with their own mind and which was the work of their own hands, I would vent my temper (cuz I’m self aware enough to know I’d still be angry) by highlighting every last error & failure, & then I’d say “Good job. Glad to see something YOU have written”.

But if 3 students came to me, and I saw they had not even bothered to change the point headers between them, I would grab their submissions and rip them to shreds in front of their eyes.

Yes ChatGPT and asking for help from friends are valuable tools to make up for your shortcomings. But remember, you are not here to pretend you do not have shortcomings, you are here to remedy them. You suck at writing? All the more reason to try to write. If its still too terrible to submit, fine, feed it to ChatGPT and say “make this pretty for me, and tell me what you did so that next time I can try to do those improvements”.

You have no idea what to include in the document? By all means refer to what someone else has done. Look at it, think for a bit, and say “oh ok I get the idea”. And then write something yourself. For most of my writing-based submissions in 12th grade, I had reference. But they were reference. I may have copied the formatting if I thought a style of pointer or font was good looking & aesthetic, but that was it. My words were my own. My work was my own.

Clarifications on Project Questions:
Updated Deadline: July 24th 11:59pm IST (accurate at the time of this edit)

Do not try to correct spelling differences. Consider every spelling difference as a different candidate / constituency.

Q1 to Q14: Use both state name and constituency name for answering these questions.

Q8: Count every deposit loss (even if its the same candidate that has lost the deposit multiple times) eg. if Carlton lost the 2024 election and the 2020 election, then that counts as 2 losses.

Q15 to Q20: Use state name for answering these questions. Therefore your target dataset is all the constituencies in the state. Some of these questions may involve your constituency in relation with other constituencies within the state.

Q16: For a given constituency, find constituencies within the same state that are less than {xxx} kms. How many of them have winners from the same party as the given constituency? Choose the latest election year for that constituency. Use Nominatim for this question.

We HIGHLY recommend using Google Sheets to write your answer (see example submission) and then export it to CSV from Google Sheets.

Submit the downloaded CSV created by Google Sheets (you can use any name for your file as long as it has the .csv extension).

CSVs created by Excel have caused numerous issues with regards to formatting.

There are no questions that require data for the whole country.

There are no questions that require data of another state. Only use your given state.

You are able to make multiple submissions just like GA. Only the latest one will be considered as the final answer.

NOTA votes are legal votes.

NOTA has no sex.

NOTA has no age.

Kind regards

Hello everyone.
I thought I’ll share this little “shocker” (at least for me). This is related to the last question of my GA5:


image
731×453 23.7 KB

While doing the GA, I used this tokenizer from OpenAI, to find the number of tokens in the above statement:

image
706×412 20.6 KB

It came out be 13, and so I multiplied with the cost per token (0.00005 cents) to get the answer 0.00065, while the accepted answer 0.0007 was defintely one token away.
As my answer didn’t match with the accepted answer, I was surprised. After scratching my head for a while, I noticed that I hadn’t put the “dot” at the end of the statement. “What difference the dot is going to make” was what I thought. Still I tried with the dot the number of tokens came out to be 14! 

image
706×412 20.5 KB

So that dot cost me around 11% of the score. A lesson learned hard.
Thank you.

The question 1 says the following

1. Identify the candidate who had the greatest change in vote share compared to the previous election,    regardless of the gap between elections? Here’s an OPTIONAL project.

Using any method
identify the Twitter accounts of heads of state of countries. (This is ambiguous. Use your judgement.)
Extract information on who follows who on Twitter.
If required for your analysis, extract any other metadata (e.g. follower count, friend count, etc.)
Publish this dataset. Ideally, everyone in the world should be able to access it without a login. Google Drive is fine.
Analyze it. Here are some ideas, but you DO NOT NEED TO USE THESE. These are just ideas.
Who’s similar? Which 2 leaders have the largest common followers as a % of their following?
Who’s opposite? If a leader follows X, do they invariably not follow Y, though Y is popular?
Who’s aloof? Who tends to follow a lot of people but follows the fewest leaders?
Who’s isolated? Who has a lot of followers but few leaders follow them?
Go beyond. For example, explore reciprocity, preferential attachment, diversity, ideology, language, follower-of-followers, network clusters, shortest paths, bridges, …
Write a short article that mentions your name and ID and shares 2 interesting and surprising (i.e. non-obvious) insights from this data. Prove it with supporting facts.
Reply to this post with a public (no login required) link to your article before Thu 4 July 2024 AoE.

s.anand

Short answer: It’s a mistake that was intentionally left uncorrected. Ignore the words difference in.

Why did I make the mistake?

Originally, my question was about the difference between 2 Pearson correlations.

Since that’s time-consuming to calculate and I felt generous, I made it a single correlation.

But I forgot to remove the words difference in.

Why didn’t I correct it later?

I remembered a client engagement. The client made an error in wording. Our team spent 8 days figuring out what the client meant. (It took just 2 days to get it done, in contrast.)

Such communication errors are common. The question is, how do we deal with them?

What should you do?

You have 3 options.

Ask. Asking gives you clarity. It requires courage and practice. But it wastes time since you need to wait (and nudge) for the answer.
Assume. Guessing the intent and proceeding saves time. You build the skill to guess intent. But you might guess wrong.
Assume, then ask. You don’t waste time. If you get an answer, you can correct. If not, you’ve done your best. Your manager / client is happy you’re not lazy and still get the job done.

In most situations, including this GA, Option 3 works best. (But if you have plenty of spare time and get only one chance, Option 1 is best.)

In this case: think about what you did for this question.

Which option did you use?
Is this your usual style?
Are there benefits to an alternate approach?

What does this have to do with TDS?

The best tool in data science is collaboration. (That’s why TDS is mostly open Internet, open collaboration, etc.)

I hope you learn to compensate for fallible faculty / managers / clients who make mistakes as often as you!

Data preparation according to me is the most difficult stage in the data analysis process. Here’s why:

Tedious and Repetitive: Data preparation often involves cleaning and wrangling messy data. This can be repetitive and time-consuming, especially for large datasets. Imagine having to fix inconsistencies, missing values, and formatting issues in thousands of rows!
Requires Attention to Detail: One mistake during data preparation can lead to inaccurate or misleading analysis. You need a keen eye to spot errors and ensure data quality.
Less Glamorous: Compared to the excitement of uncovering insights or building models, data preparation might feel less glamorous. It’s the groundwork that goes unseen but is crucial for successful analysis.

While other stages have their challenges, data preparation can feel particularly troublesome because of its repetitive nature and the importance of getting it right.

Dear TDS team,
For calculations should we include both corner cases such as 10:00 and 20:00 , or include 10:00 but exclude 20:00 or exclude 10:00 and 20:00 both ? The question is in between does it include boundaries ?
Thanks and regards
Jivraj



 Solved by s.anand in post #2
Marked as solved by s.anand
These intervals follow the Python convention of right-open intervals. They include the lower but exclude the higher values. In this case, you would include 10:00:00 but exclude 20:00:00. The logic would roughly be "10:00" <= time < "20:00"

Usually we don’t ask questions about graded assignments till after their respective deadlines but my question here is not regarding what the correct answers are (I was able to get those), but more about what the optimal way to go about such a task is.

For context the questions ask us to identify the official data portal of Colombia & Peru respectively.

First thing I tried, lifted straight from the lectures - check the awesome-public-datasets page. No dice.

Next thing I tried - going to google-dataset-search, just typing Peru, seeing who uploaded each of the dataset results which showed up. Still no dice.

Next thing was just googling “Official data portal peru” like a chimp. That eventually led me to the correct link but ONLY because this was an MCQ based assignment & I knew the “correct link” would be 1 of 4 options. If it were not for those mcqs in front of me, this may have been a different story. Also doesn’t help that my Spanish is rudimentary at best.

My broader question is about how we find what we’re looking for and also how we then figure out if we’ve legitimately found what it is we were looking for, but I suspect the answer to that is a combination of “practice” + “experience” + “don’t be stupid”.

So I’ll confine my question right now to asking if there’s anything glaringly obvious that I did not try while trying to find the answer for these questions?

May seem like a strange question to ask, but over some of the programming diploma subjects I learnt an unfortunate side-effect of the “learn by figuring large chunks of it out for yourself” school of teaching, namely that you learn bad/inefficient/janky practices.
After all if I’m a caveman who’s never seen a wheel before, and I’m tasked with making a thing that rolls, I may well stop at an octagonal shaped “wheel” because hey that does roll; the thought of a circle won’t even cross my mind.

My overall point is that left to myself I tend to go with brute force ways to solve problems that either take 8 times as much effort or (in rare cases, I usually throw enough force to negate this) don’t work at all, hence my asking such questions as a countermeasure for that tendency

Since there are lots are queries related to TDS project - 1, Jan 2024 term. So here I am trying to clear doubts.

Please use the dataset as is , even when there is a minor difference in the name of candidate/party/constituency. For Example there can be multiple candidates with similar name , consider each name as unique individual : Eg Chandrasekhar Rao is different from Chandra Sekhar Rao. Consider both the records as individual contestants.
2: For Bihar, there were 2 sets of elections conducted for the same year 2005. Please use the following link to access the modified dataset for easy evaluation:

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/122jbsUdXqJktBOj21pjjSZ0Yh6fsoSxp–PzdTM8KN0/edit#gid=1831749757

Q3: "In which year did the highest number of female candidates contest?" If no female candidate has ever contested in any election, the answer should be 0. In cases where the number of female candidates is the same for multiple years, the answer should be the earliest year. For example, if the highest number of female candidates is 4 in both 1994 and 2005, then the answer must be 1994.
q 4 : Margin percentage definition is given in instructions of project-1. Use that def. to calculate answer.
Q 6 : just simple margin. not %

q 14 : Which year did a party exhibit the most significant increase in vote share from one election to the next consecutive one?
This denotes the party that exhibited the most significant increase in vote share from one election to the next consecutive one? Exclude parties that did not contest in the subsequent consecutive election.
If no party participate in consecutive elections then

Name of project 1 answer file : your_roll_number.csv
example : 21f1005763.csv

Data type of certain Questions :
some questions data types are mis-printed. Here are the correct one
1 : Name string
2 : Integer
3 : year, Integer
4 : Float. decimal 2 places. example : 23.45
5 : Year integer
6 : Integer : maximum votes - minimum votes. a simple number.
7 : Year Integer
8 : Integer
9 : integer
10 : Year Integer
11 : Name string
12 : Name string
13 : Float. decimal 2 places. example : 23.45
14 : Year integer

In party related questions, Consider "IND" as one single Party.
CSV file related problem :
use Google sheets.
write number of questions in given order. Don't write them in ascending order. Just write them as they r given.
download it in your computer in .csv format and upload it on portal

some ppl are still getting error because they r using ms exel. they r getting some **{\ufefff** type of error. for it open your file in in built notepad and remove unwanted string and ctrl+S and upload again.
If on submitting your test score is 100/100 then your format is correct.

ignore 0/0 private case passed stuff. there r no private cases in this project.

Amit1
Mar 2024

Dear TDS members,

Please find below clarifications regarding TDS Project 1 submission:

Clarification 1:
Regarding Q3: “In which year did the highest number of female candidates contest?” If no female candidate has ever contested in any election, the answer should be 0. In cases where the number of female candidates is the same for multiple years, the answer should be the earliest year. For example, if the highest number of female candidates is 4 in both 1994 and 2005, then the answer must be 1994.

Clarification 2:
For Bihar, there were 2 sets of elections conducted for the same year 2005. Please use the following link to access the modified dataset for easy evaluation:

docs.google.com
assembly_dataset2_corrected

assembly_dataset2.csv ST_NAME,YEAR,AC_NO,#,AC_NAME,AC_TYPE,NAME,SEX,AGE,CATEGORY,PARTY,VOTES Bihar,1951,1,1,MANER,GEN,RAMESHWAR PRASAD SHASTRI,M,NODATA,INC,8240 Bihar,1951,1,2,MANER,GEN,JAGDEO PRASAD...

Clarification 3:
Regarding Q14: “Which year did the party exhibit the most significant increase in vote share from one election to the next consecutive one?” The expected answer should be an integer and not a float.

Clarification 4:
Please use the dataset as it is , even when there is a minor difference in the name of candidate/party/constituency. For Example there can be multiple candidates with similar name , consider each name as unique individual :
Eg Chandrasekhar Rao is different from Chandra Sekhar Rao (or Chandrashekhar Rao). Consider both the records as individual contestants.

Clarification 5:
Q14: Which year did a party exhibit the most significant increase in vote share from one election to the next consecutive one?
This denotes the party that exhibited the most significant increase in vote share from one election to the next consecutive one? Exclude parties that did not contest in the subsequent consecutive election

Thank you for your attention to these clarifications.

Regards
TDS team

print(sorted(tige.items(), key =

Hey guys

I wanted to share a quick tip that might come in handy, especially in numeric response questions.

When faced with a numeric question that requires a percentage as an answer, consider providing your response in fractional form. For example, if your answer is “m%”, refrain from simply writing “m.” Instead, represent the percentage as a fraction by dividing the value by 100.

sayan
Oct 2023

If you are facing problems with Nominatim like Authorization error, it is due to the user_agent being blacklisted. (myGeocoder) Instead use any unique string like your roll number or name instead.

agent = Nominatim(user_agent='21f1001234')
location = agent.geocode('Kolkata')


Also, if you are not getting the correct city for the search, for example if you search for Bethlehem but get

Belém, Região Geográfica Imediata de Belém, Região Geográfica Intermediária de Belém, Pará, Região Norte, Brasil


instead, then try to switch to the Photon agent instead. This worked for me.

agent = Photon(user_agent='21f1001234')
location = agent.geocode('Bethlehem')


gave the correct output

Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, United States

It would have been highly beneficial if the exam paper had been provided in a standard file format. Since Excel cannot be installed on Ubuntu, this led to stress and wasted time. As a result, I lost marks, which is very frustrating.

This led to substantial delays as I made repeated attempts to access it, and when I finally managed to copy the content to a new personal spreadsheet, I discovered that only “District = 1” was present. This was incredibly frustrating and consumed half of the given time.

These issues are particularly concerning as they cover a significant portion of the exam’s marks. Dixon
Mar 2023

We’ve assessed the concerns raised in RoE. Please find our responses to the predominant concerns raised.

1. Not enough time.


This was intentional. It’s okay to not answer all questions. We emphasized this in the guidelines as well as in our live sessions.

2. COVID excel dataset had missing column names.


Students will be awarded marks for the 3 questions that required information about new cases and new deaths.

3. Imdb scraping exercise


Students who got the following question and marked “Biography” as answer will be awarded marks.


image
749×376 66.6 KB

4. Excel question movie ratings


a) Students will be awarded marks for the question “Number of movies having rating >=8.1 and <=8”.

b) For the question “Number of movies for each rating (Frequency)” - Students who got rating of 8.2, 8.3, 8.4, 8.5 will be awarded marks”.

c) For the question “For the year assigned, rating with maximum number of movies is(For example in an year if two movies got rating of 8.3 and 3 movies got rating of 8.1" answer is 8.1) - Students who got year 2000 and 2023 will be awarded marks

5. Timers wrongly timed


Students were informed on multiple occasions that the exam is only for half an hour. The last announcement on TDS RoE about the guidelines also mentioned the same.

6. Is there relative grading?


No not for the RoE. We will have a look at the cumulative scores at the end and make any decision then.

Q10: What is the highest absolute difference in percentage between yea and nay senators among the different parties?

I am not clear with the understanding of this question. Humble request to explain what is this question trying to ask?



 Solved by rohithsrinivaas in post #8
Marked as solved by rohithsrinivaas
Every party has A percent of Yea senators and B percent of Nay senators. The absolute difference is |A-B|. This quantity is measured for every party and then the max value of this quantity across all parties is the required answer. (EDITED)

My God!!! After “using” TDS for the last couple of weeks, here is my review.

TDS has the best support group (or non-support group, I am confused!!!) ever. They will support your growth by a new method called " Non-support induced growth". Question from Mock Questions Document

Q17) Compute the levenshtein distance between the two strings provided below:
String 1: K & M Associates, Inc
String 2: K & J Associates, Ltd
a) 0
b) 2
c) 4
d) 5

—> Solution for the Levenshtein distance question:

String 1: K & M Associates, Inc
String 2: K & J Associates, Ltd

Going letter by letter from left to right if you were to obtain string 2 from string 1, you would have to make minimum 4 replacements:
M to J
I to L
N to T
C to D

Hence, the number of insertions, deletions and replacements required is 4, which is the answer.

Q14 - Predict sentiment using Textblob. How many positive titles (title) are there [books.csv] ? (cut-off >0) N

My sentiment analysis displays two columns:

Sentiment [‘positive’,‘neutral’,‘negative’]
Score [0,1]

Any title which scores a value around 0.5 (say 0.53), gets assigned the Sentiment = ‘Neutral’. However the Q asks us to “tag” these as Positive (as per Question statement - cut-off>0).

I am writing the method that I plan to use. I have tried it for question 6 and I guess this should work for other questions too.

Create an excel file where each tab is the four csv files (you can open the csv file and copy the tab to the other file)
For these tabs - book_tags, ratings, toread, add two columns called orig_title and title
Use vlookup to populate these fields from books tab
Create a pivot with all the columns (it does not take long time though there are many rows)
Put orig_title in filters part and filter out blank values (vlookup may put them as zero)
Then do the calculations as needed - for question 6, it would be the sum of counts column and the max value in that

Hope this helps

The folder number is used to randomize the data for the students. Double check that the folder number in the portal number and in the drive link are the same.

Q10. This uses the same algo as question 6. But get the least of the sum. Unlike question 6, the id should be the answer and not the title

Q14 - cut-off is indeed > 0; use textblob module in python (the video uses the same method)

Q16 - Flourish puts the bins in y-axis by default… You can use either the default bar chart, or change the type to column chart … No animation is required. You may choose to omit buckets that are empty.

#!/usr/bin/env python
# coding: utf-8

# In[89]:


import tabula
import numpy
import pandas as pd


# In[90]:


pdf_path = r"C:\Users\sadin\Downloads\kerala-2006.pdf"
dfs = tabula.read_pdf(pdf_path,pages="15-19" ,stream=True)


# In[4]:


dfs[0]


# In[91]:


temp=dfs[0]
temp=temp[temp['FEMALE  CANDIDATES'].isnull()==False]
temp=temp.drop([1,3])
temp['Candidate']=temp['Unnamed: 0'].apply(lambda x : ' '.join(x.split()[1:]))
temp['Party']=temp['FEMALE  CANDIDATES'].apply(lambda x : x.split()[0])
temp['Votes Polled']=temp['FEMALE  CANDIDATES'].apply(lambda x : int(x.split()[1]))
temp=temp[['Candidate','Party','Votes Polled']]
page1=temp
temp


# In[92]:


temp=dfs[1]
temp=temp[temp['Unnamed: 0'].isnull()==False]
temp=temp.drop(0)
temp['Candidate']=temp['CONSTITUENCY'].apply(lambda x: ' '.join(x.split()[1:]))
temp['Votes Polled']=temp['Unnamed: 1'].apply(lambda x: int(x.split()[0]))
temp['Party']=temp['Unnamed: 0']
temp=temp[['Candidate','Party','Votes Polled']]
page2=temp
temp


# In[93]:


temp=dfs[2]
temp=temp[temp['Unnamed: 0'].isnull()==False]
temp=temp.drop(0)
temp['Candidate']=temp['CONSTITUENCY'].apply(lambda x: ' '.join(x.split()[1:]))
temp['Votes Polled']=temp['Unnamed: 1'].apply(lambda x: int(x.split()[0]))
temp['Party']=temp['Unnamed: 0']
temp=temp[['Candidate','Party','Votes Polled']]
page3=temp
temp


# In[94]:


temp=dfs[3]
temp=temp[temp['Unnamed: 1'].isnull()==False]
temp=temp.drop([0,2])
temp['Candidate']=temp['CONSTITUENCY'].apply(lambda x: ' '.join(x.split()[1:-1]))
temp['Votes Polled']=temp['Unnamed: 1'].apply(lambda x: int(x.split()[0]))
temp['Party']=temp['CONSTITUENCY'].apply(lambda x: x.split()[-1])
temp=temp[['Candidate','Party','Votes Polled']]
page4=temp
temp


# In[95]:


final_data = pd.concat([page1,page2,page3,page4], axis=0)


# In[96]:


final_data


# In[97]:


x=final_data['Votes Polled'].sum()
x


# In[98]:


x/70

Hi @22t1_se2002 Team:
Appreciate the Project 2 coming online.

We wanted to share a tip: Use UTF Encoding for non-English (specially non-Latin and non-Cyrillic). And look for data internationalization techniques.

We got the data from the original source GitHub - zygmunt/good books-10k: Ten thousand books, six million ratings and applied the XSLT filters to match the CSV file in the data set.

It applied the UTF Encoding from the original source and we added columns to get English Titles & Authors for the ISBN. {\MATCH ISBN13,GET\BookTitle\BookAuthors, \MATCH ISBN,GET\BookTitle\BookAuthors)

I was going through this activity online and needed feedback on this study design experiment. I am doing it for the first time and the following is what I wrote (with fictitious names, of course). This is not a part of any assignment or homework.

To : Charles Ferguson, CEO, Pizzeria
From: Robert November, Marketing Consultant
Date: --/–/----
Subject: Comparative Statistical Study Design – Pizzeria and Pizza Maniacs

This study design aims at designing a pipeline for data collection and subsequent statistical analysis of the data to help Pizzeria get an edge in the market over their competitor Pizza Maniacs.
Data Collection
To obtain sufficient data on the sale of pizza, it is recommended to push feedback notifications while people order online. Manual feedback can be obtained from the people dining in. Questions that need to be included are:

What differentiates us from the other pizza chains?
(a) Crust (b) Variety of Toppings (c) Ambience (d) Fast Delivery

How satisfied were you with the last order quality?
(a) Very Satisfied (b) Somewhat Satisfied (c) Not Satisfied (d) Won’t be back again

How likely are you to recommend us to family or friends?
(a) 1 (b) 2 (c) 3 (d) 4 (e) 5

How satisfied were you with the delivery/service staff?
(a) Very Satisfied (b) Somewhat Satisfied (c) Not Satisfied (d) Won’t be back again

How did you know about us?
(a) Social Media (b) Print Media (c) Friends or Family (d) Other

Data Analysis
Uniqueness: Based on the data collected, we first need to check for our Unique Selling Proposition (USP) – that is what differentiates us from the others. Based on this analysis, we need to get better at these or introduce more options. A pie chart is sufficient to analyze this variable.
Customer Satisfaction (quality and service): This is an ordinal variable. We need to get the count of these ratings amongst each age group so that we know which age group our pizzas appeal the most to. We can then focus on creating appropriate content and introduce offers that appeal to them. A clustered bar chart should be enough to summarize this data.
Advertisement: This is a qualitative variable and should tell us which segment of advertisement brings us the most customers. If an anomaly is observed, like we are spending in a mode of advertisement that would bring little to no customers, it’s better to focus on another segment of advertisement. A scatterplot with the internal data of advertisement spending and the count of the customers that each segment brings us should be enough to understand the issue.
Recommendation: Although this is an ordinal variable, this can be considered as a ratio variable and the standard deviations of the ratings can be checked. If the standard deviation is high, it means that a certain section is highly unsatisfied or a section is highly satisfied, or both. Suitable changes can be implemented after further investigation of the issue.
Advertisement:
Our advertisement needs to address these issues graphically so that people know what we are better at. A clustered bar chart of our food items’ categorical popularity in contrast with our competitors would definitely appeal to the masses. Based on the data collected, the advertisement should also mention fast delivery times and the margins by which we deliver before others. Color combination and other design factors can be fixated on the age group we are trying to appeal to.
Any constructive feedback from instructors or my fellow learners will be highly appreciated.
Thanks in advance
Abhik Biswas
